text: Resolution adopted by the General Assembly on 19 December 2024
[on the report of the Second Committee (A/79/439, para. 11)]
79/215.	Towards a New International Economic Order
The General Assembly,

Recalling its resolutions 55/186 of 20 December 2000 and 56/181 of 21 December 2001, entitled “Towards a strengthened and stable international financial architecture responsive to the priorities of growth and development, especially in developing countries, and to the promotion of economic and social equity”, as well as its resolutions 57/241 of 20 December 2002, 58/202 of 23 December 2003, 59/222 of 22 December 2004, 60/186 of 22 December 2005, 61/187 of 20 December 2006, 62/185 of 19 December 2007, 63/205 of 19 December 2008, 64/190 of 21 December 2009, 65/143 of 20 December 2010, 66/187 of 22 December 2011, 67/197 of 21 December 2012, 68/201 of 20 December 2013, 69/206 of 19 December 2014, 70/188 of 22 December 2015, 71/215 of 21 December 2016, 72/203 of 20 December 2017, 73/220 of 20 December 2018, 74/202 of 19 December 2019, 75/204 of 21 December 2020, 76/192 of 17 December 2021, 77/152 of 14 December 2022 and 78/136 of 19 December 2023,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* its resolutions 55/186 of 20 December 2000 and 56/181 of 21 December 2001, entitled “Towards a strengthened and stable international financial architecture responsive to the priorities of growth and development, especially in developing countries, and to the promotion of economic and social equity”, as well as its resolutions 57/241 of 20 December 2002, 58/202 of 23 December 2003, 59/222 of 22 December 2004, 60/186 of 22 December 2005, 61/187 of 20 December 2006, 62/185 of 19 December 2007, 63/205 of 19 December 2008, 64/190 of 21 December 2009, 65/143 of 20 December 2010, 66/187 of 22 December 2011, 67/197 of 21 December 2012, 68/201 of 20 December 2013, 69/206 of 19 December 2014, 70/188 of 22 December 2015, 71/215 of 21 December 2016, 72/203 of 20 December 2017, 73/220 of 20 December 2018, 74/202 of 19 December 2019, 75/204 of 21 December 2020, 76/192 of 17 December 2021, 77/152 of 14 December 2022 and 78/136 of 19 December 2023,

text: Bearing in mind the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations to promote the economic advancement and social progress of all peoples,
textWithHighlights: *Bearing in mind* the purposes and principles of the Charter of the United Nations to promote the economic advancement and social progress of all peoples,

text: Recalling, especially in the year of their fiftieth anniversary, the principles of the Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order, as set out in resolutions 3201 (S-VI) and 3202 (S-VI), respectively, adopted by the General Assembly at its sixth special session, on 1 May 1974,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling*, especially in the year of their fiftieth anniversary, the principles of the Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order, as set out in resolutions 3201 (S-VI) and 3202 (S-VI), respectively, adopted by the {{General Assembly}} at its sixth special session, on 1 May 1974,

text: Recalling also its resolutions 63/224 of 19 December 2008, 64/209 of 21 December 2009, 65/167 of 20 December 2010, 67/217 of 21 December 2012, 69/227 of 19 December 2014, 71/236 of 21 December 2016, 73/240 of 20 December 2018, 75/225 of 21 December 2020 and 77/174 of 14 December 2022,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling also* its resolutions 63/224 of 19 December 2008, 64/209 of 21 December 2009, 65/167 of 20 December 2010, 67/217 of 21 December 2012, 69/227 of 19 December 2014, 71/236 of 21 December 2016, 73/240 of 20 December 2018, 75/225 of 21 December 2020 and 77/174 of 14 December 2022,

text: Reaffirming the United Nations Millennium Declaration,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* the United Nations Millennium Declaration,

text: Recalling the high-level plenary meeting of the General Assembly on the Millennium Development Goals and its outcome document,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the high-level plenary meeting of the {{General Assembly}} on the Millennium Development Goals and its outcome document,

text: Recalling also the outcome document of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, entitled “The future we want”,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling also* the outcome document of the United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development, entitled “The future we want”,

text: Reaffirming its resolution 70/1 of 25 September 2015, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, in which it adopted a comprehensive, far-reaching and people-centred set of universal and transformative Sustainable Development Goals and targets, its commitment to working tirelessly for the full implementation of the Agenda by 2030, its recognition that eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and an indispensable requirement for sustainable development, its commitment to achieving sustainable development in its three dimensions – economic, social and environmental – in a balanced and integrated manner, and to building upon the achievements of the Millennium Development Goals and seeking to address their unfinished business,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming* its resolution 70/1 of 25 September 2015, entitled “Transforming our world: the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development”, in which it adopted a comprehensive, far-reaching and people-centred set of universal and transformative Sustainable Development Goals and targets, its commitment to working tirelessly for the full implementation of the Agenda by 2030, its recognition that eradicating poverty in all its forms and dimensions, including extreme poverty, is the greatest global challenge and an indispensable requirement for sustainable development, its commitment to achieving sustainable development in its three dimensions – economic, social and environmental – in a balanced and integrated manner, and to building upon the achievements of the Millennium Development Goals and seeking to address their unfinished business,

text: Reaffirming also its resolution 69/313 of 27 July 2015 on the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, which is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, supports and complements it, helps to contextualize its means of implementation targets with concrete policies and actions, and reaffirms the strong political commitment to address the challenge of financing and creating an enabling environment at all levels for sustainable development in the spirit of global partnership and solidarity,
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirming also* its resolution 69/313 of 27 July 2015 on the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development, which is an integral part of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, supports and complements it, helps to contextualize its means of implementation targets with concrete policies and actions, and reaffirms the strong political commitment to address the challenge of financing and creating an enabling environment at all levels for sustainable development in the spirit of global partnership and solidarity,
uncertainties: Verbs like 'supports', 'helps', and 'reaffirms' in the relative clause describe the Addis Ababa Action Agenda, not the Assembly's action; therefore they are not treated as operative verbs here. No concrete assignees or deliverables appear in this preambular paragraph.

text: Recalling the outcomes of the major United Nations conferences and summits in the economic, social and related fields, including the development goals and objectives contained therein, and recognizing the vital role played by those conferences and summits in shaping a broad development vision and in identifying commonly agreed objectives,
textWithHighlights: *Recalling* the outcomes of the major United Nations conferences and summits in the economic, social and related fields, including the development goals and objectives contained therein, and *recognizing* the vital role played by those conferences and summits in shaping a broad development vision and in identifying commonly agreed objectives,

text: Stressing the need to fulfil all financing for development commitments, including those contained in the Monterrey Consensus of the International Conference on Financing for Development, the Doha Declaration on Financing for Development: outcome document of the Follow-up International Conference on Financing for Development to Review the Implementation of the Monterrey Consensus, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda and other relevant outcomes of major United Nations conferences and summits,
textWithHighlights: *Stressing* the need to fulfil all financing for development commitments, including those contained in the Monterrey Consensus of the International Conference on Financing for Development, the Doha Declaration on Financing for Development: outcome document of the Follow-up International Conference on Financing for Development to Review the Implementation of the Monterrey Consensus, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda and other relevant outcomes of major United Nations conferences and summits,

text: Noting that there have been systemic challenges to the global economic architecture, demanding a review of global economic governance, calling for the reform of the international financial system and the relevant institutions and the broadening and strengthening of the voice and participation of developing countries in international economic decision-making and norm-setting and in global economic governance, in order to address the unique needs and capacities of developing countries when designing macroeconomic policies, recognizing that it is important that the International Monetary Fund continue to be adequately resourced, and supporting and reiterating its commitment to further governance reform at both the Fund and the World Bank to adapt to changes in the global economy,
textWithHighlights: *Noting* that there have been systemic challenges to the global economic architecture, demanding a review of global economic governance, calling for the reform of the international financial system and the relevant institutions and the broadening and strengthening of the voice and participation of {{developing countries}} in international economic decision-making and norm-setting and in global economic governance, in order to address the unique needs and capacities of {{developing countries}} when designing macroeconomic policies, *recognizing* that it is important that the {{International Monetary Fund}} continue to be adequately resourced, and *supporting* and *reiterating* its commitment to further governance reform at both the Fund and the {{World Bank}} to adapt to changes in the global economy,
uncertainties: The participles "demanding" and "calling for" likely describe what the systemic challenges entail, rather than actions by the Assembly, so they were not treated as operative verbs or linked to deliverables. No concrete deliverables were extracted from "supporting"/"reiterating" since they express stance/commitment rather than specific tasks.

text: Noting with great concern the severe negative impact on human health, safety and well-being caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as the severe disruption to societies and economies and the devastating impact on lives and livelihoods, and that the poorest and most vulnerable are the hardest hit by the pandemic, reaffirming the ambition to get back on track to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by designing and implementing sustainable and inclusive recovery strategies to accelerate progress towards the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to help to reduce the risk of and build resilience to future shocks, crises and pandemics, including by strengthening health systems and achieving universal health coverage, and recognizing that equitable and timely access for all to safe, quality, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics are an essential part of a global response based on unity, solidarity, renewed multilateral cooperation and the principle of leaving no one behind,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with great concern* the severe negative impact on human health, safety and well-being caused by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) pandemic, as well as the severe disruption to societies and economies and the devastating impact on lives and livelihoods, and that the poorest and most vulnerable are the hardest hit by the pandemic, *reaffirming* the ambition to get back on track to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals by designing and implementing sustainable and inclusive recovery strategies to accelerate progress towards the full implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and to help to reduce the risk of and build resilience to future shocks, crises and pandemics, including by strengthening health systems and achieving universal health coverage, and *recognizing* that equitable and timely access for all to safe, quality, effective and affordable COVID-19 vaccines, therapeutics and diagnostics are an essential part of a global response based on unity, solidarity, renewed multilateral cooperation and the principle of leaving no one behind,

text: Recognizing that achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is intrinsically linked to the successful implementation of the Addis Ababa Action Agenda, emphasizing that additional and timely financing is essential to reach the Goals by 2030, and in this regard stressing the urgent need for the adequate mobilization of resources,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that achieving the Sustainable Development Goals is intrinsically linked to the successful implementation of the Addis Ababa Action Agenda, *emphasizing* that additional and timely financing is essential to reach the Goals by 2030, and in this regard *stressing* the urgent need for the adequate mobilization of resources,

text: Noting with concern that the total external debt of developing countries reached a record level of 11.4 trillion United States dollars in 2023, an increase of 3.4 per cent, and deeply concerned that 3.3 billion people live in developing countries that spend more on interest payments than on either education or health, limiting further countries’ abilities to invest in sustainable development and the implementation of the 2030 Agenda,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with concern* that the total external debt of {{developing countries}} reached a record level of 11.4 trillion United States dollars in 2023, an increase of 3.4 per cent, and *deeply concerned* that 3.3 billion people live in {{developing countries}} that spend more on interest payments than on either education or health, limiting further countries’ abilities to invest in sustainable development and the implementation of the 2030 Agenda,

text: Concerned that more countries have been paying International Monetary Fund surcharges, which add extra costs for precisely those countries that face the most severe balance of payment challenges,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned* that more countries have been paying {{International Monetary Fund}} surcharges, which add extra costs for precisely those countries that face the most severe balance of payment challenges,

text: Recognizing the need to help developing countries to bridge financing gaps, including when it comes to disparities in financial costs and in access to technologies to fully achieve a digital transition, stressing that the financing needs of developing countries remain very high, and calling for the reform of the international financial architecture,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the need to help {{developing countries}} to bridge financing gaps, including when it comes to disparities in financial costs and in access to technologies to fully achieve a digital transition, *stressing* that the financing needs of {{developing countries}} remain very high, and *calling for* the reform of the international financial architecture,

text: Concerned about the multiple interrelated and mutually exacerbating current global crises, in particular the world financial and economic crisis, volatile energy and commodity prices, the food crisis and the challenges posed by climate change, which have a negative impact on the development prospects of developing countries and threaten to further widen the gap between developed and developing countries, including the technological and income gap, and which could further undermine the achievement of the internationally agreed development goals, including the Sustainable Development Goals,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned about* the multiple interrelated and mutually exacerbating current global crises, in particular the world financial and economic crisis, volatile energy and commodity prices, the food crisis and the challenges posed by climate change, which have a negative impact on the development prospects of {{developing countries}} and threaten to further widen the gap between developed and {{developing countries}}, including the technological and income gap, and which could further undermine the achievement of the internationally agreed development goals, including the Sustainable Development Goals,
uncertainties: The phrase 'developed and developing countries' does not explicitly repeat 'countries' after 'developed'; therefore only 'developing countries' is highlighted/extracted as a mentioned entity to maintain exact text matching.

text: Concerned also, in this regard, that the proportion of workers living in extreme poverty, including workers in the informal economy, continues to increase, as does the proportion of the population living on less than 1.90 dollars a day, and that progress towards ending extreme poverty has been reversed by three to four years at the global level,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned also*, in this regard, that the proportion of workers living in extreme poverty, including workers in the informal economy, continues to increase, as does the proportion of the population living on less than 1.90 dollars a day, and that progress towards ending extreme poverty has been reversed by three to four years at the global level,

text: Concerned further about recent economic developments in the context of the continued challenges to achieving sustained economic growth, in which persistently high levels of inequality pose a challenge to robust growth and sustainable development, declining private investment in infrastructure highlights the obstacles to bridging the infrastructure financing gap and advancing the long-term financing of sustainable development, emerging debt challenges and vulnerabilities have intensified across developing countries, global exchange rate volatility has intensified and global inflationary trends have diverged, and that the weak prospects for the global economy put at risk vital public investment in education, health and action on climate change, as well as progress in poverty eradication, especially in developing countries,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned further* about recent economic developments in the context of the continued challenges to achieving sustained economic growth, in which persistently high levels of inequality pose a challenge to robust growth and sustainable development, declining private investment in infrastructure highlights the obstacles to bridging the infrastructure financing gap and advancing the long-term financing of sustainable development, emerging debt challenges and vulnerabilities have intensified across {{developing countries}}, global exchange rate volatility has intensified and global inflationary trends have diverged, and that the weak prospects for the global economy put at risk vital public investment in education, health and action on climate change, as well as progress in poverty eradication, especially in {{developing countries}},

text: Concerned that billions of the world’s citizens continue to live in poverty and are denied a life of dignity and that there are rising inequalities within and among countries and enormous disparities of opportunity, wealth and power,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned* that billions of the world’s citizens continue to live in poverty and are denied a life of dignity and that there are rising inequalities within and among countries and enormous disparities of opportunity, wealth and power,

text: Stressing the lack of strong coordinated international response in dealing with the challenges referred to above, illustrating that the calls made in the Declaration and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order are still highly relevant,

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order
Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order

textWithHighlights: *Stressing* the lack of strong coordinated international response in dealing with the challenges referred to above, illustrating that the calls made in the {{Declaration}} and the {{Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order}} are still highly relevant,
uncertainties: The participle 'illustrating' is not in the exhaustive operative verb list; treated as narrative and not extracted as an operative verb.

text: Underlining the need for a more sustainable economic growth and recovery, and recognizing that this goal can be achieved through inclusive multilateralism and the equal participation of all countries, as envisioned, inter alia, in the Declaration and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order,
textWithHighlights: *Underlining* the need for a more sustainable economic growth and recovery, and *recognizing* that this goal can be achieved through inclusive multilateralism and the equal participation of all countries, as envisioned, inter alia, in the Declaration and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order,

text: Recognizing that innovative and enhanced approaches to financing for development are needed to address the challenges posed by the current global economic situation, poverty and the achievement of the internationally agreed development goals, including the Sustainable Development Goals, and stressing that these approaches should neither be a substitute for nor negatively affect the level of traditional sources of development financing, including official development assistance and concessional finance, and that they need to be developed in a spirit of partnership, cooperation and solidarity, bearing in mind the common interests and national priorities of each country,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* that innovative and enhanced approaches to financing for development are needed to address the challenges posed by the current global economic situation, poverty and the achievement of the internationally agreed development goals, including the Sustainable Development Goals, and *stressing* that these approaches should neither be a substitute for nor negatively affect the level of traditional sources of development financing, including official development assistance and concessional finance, and that they need to be developed in a spirit of partnership, cooperation and solidarity, *bearing in mind* the common interests and national priorities of each country,

text: Noting with regret that, 50 years later, many relevant aspects of the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order have not been implemented and that, consequently, many developing countries continue to face significant challenges to their development prospects, including vulnerability to external shocks and lack of adequate representation in global economic governance,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with regret* that, 50 years later, many relevant aspects of the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order have not been implemented and that, consequently, many {{developing countries}} continue to face significant challenges to their development prospects, including vulnerability to external shocks and lack of adequate representation in global economic governance,

text: Recognizing the role played by regional, subregional and interregional cooperation as well as regional economic integration, based on equality of partnership, in strengthening international cooperation with the objective of facilitating economic coordination and cooperation for development, the achievement of development goals and the sharing of best practices and knowledge,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* the role played by regional, subregional and interregional cooperation as well as regional economic integration, based on equality of partnership, in strengthening international cooperation with the objective of facilitating economic coordination and cooperation for development, the achievement of development goals and the sharing of best practices and knowledge,

text: Recognizing also that widespread financial deregulation has contributed to larger net capital outflows from developing countries to developed countries,
textWithHighlights: *Recognizing* also that widespread financial deregulation has contributed to larger net capital outflows from {{developing countries}} to {{developed countries}},

text: Noting with deep concern the impact of illicit financial flows on the economic, social and political stability and development of developing countries, resulting in the urgent need to adopt measures to combat them, which could enhance fiscal space for Governments to finance the achievement of the 2030 Agenda,
textWithHighlights: *Noting with deep concern* the impact of illicit financial flows on the economic, social and political stability and development of {{developing countries}}, resulting in the urgent need to adopt measures to combat them, which could enhance fiscal space for Governments to finance the achievement of the 2030 Agenda,

text: Stressing the need for policy space to allow for the formulation of national development strategies by developing countries, aimed at bringing prosperity for all,
textWithHighlights: *Stressing* the need for policy space to allow for the formulation of national development strategies by {{developing countries}}, aimed at bringing prosperity for all,

text: Concerned with the increasing protectionist measures and adoption of inward-looking policies that undermine the multilateral trading system and increase the vulnerabilities of developing countries, and emphasizing the importance of promoting an open world economy and generating greater positive effects of globalization,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned* with the increasing protectionist measures and adoption of inward-looking policies that undermine the multilateral trading system and increase the vulnerabilities of {{developing countries}}, and *emphasizing* the importance of promoting an open world economy and generating greater positive effects of globalization,

text: Emphasizing that multilateralism, including a universal, rules-based, open, transparent, predictable, inclusive, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system, is the most appropriate platform of international cooperation for addressing the challenges facing humanity,
textWithHighlights: *Emphasizing* that multilateralism, including a universal, rules-based, open, transparent, predictable, inclusive, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system, is the most appropriate platform of international cooperation for addressing the challenges facing humanity,

text: Concerned about the financial risks associated with ongoing monetary policy adjustments in developed countries, which could induce instability in the international monetary system, leading to exchange rate depreciation and unsustainable levels of external debt in many developing and emerging economies,
textWithHighlights: *Concerned* about the financial risks associated with ongoing monetary policy adjustments in {{developed countries}}, which could induce instability in the international monetary system, leading to exchange rate depreciation and unsustainable levels of external debt in many {{developing and emerging economies}},
uncertainties: "developing and emerging economies" is not a standard category in the entity list; kept as type 'other' to preserve the exact reference.

text: Takes note of the report of the Secretary-General;
textWithHighlights: *Takes note* of the report of the {{Secretary-General}};

text: Notes that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development and the Paris Agreement adopted under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change carry forward many of the ideas and recommendations of the Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

textWithHighlights: *Notes* that the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development, the Addis Ababa Action Agenda of the Third International Conference on Financing for Development and the Paris Agreement adopted under the {{United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change}} carry forward many of the ideas and recommendations of the Declaration on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order;

text: Reaffirms the need to continue working towards a new international economic order based on the principles of equity, sovereign equality, interdependence, common interest, cooperation and solidarity among all States;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the need to continue working towards a new international economic order based on the principles of equity, sovereign equality, interdependence, common interest, cooperation and solidarity among all {{States}};
uncertainties: Interpreted “States” as Member States; no concrete deliverables identified.

text: Reiterates that States are strongly urged to refrain from promulgating and applying any unilateral economic, financial or trade measures not in accordance with international law and the Charter of the United Nations that impede the full achievement of economic and social development, particularly in developing countries;
textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* that {{States}} are strongly urged to refrain from promulgating and applying any unilateral economic, financial or trade measures not in accordance with international law and the Charter of the {{United Nations}} that impede the full achievement of economic and social development, particularly in {{developing countries}};
uncertainties: The clause embeds a directive (“States are strongly urged to refrain…”), but the main operative verb of the paragraph is “Reiterates”, so no assignees or deliverables are extracted.

text: Reaffirms that national development efforts need to be supported by an enabling international economic environment, including coherent and mutually supporting world trade, monetary and financial systems and strengthened and enhanced global economic governance, as well as by respect for each country’s policy space;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* that national development efforts need to be supported by an enabling international economic environment, including coherent and mutually supporting world trade, monetary and financial systems and strengthened and enhanced global economic governance, as well as by respect for each country’s policy space;

text: Welcomes the Secretary-General’s call for a new Bretton Woods moment to place the dramatic needs of developing countries at the centre of every decision and mechanism of the global financial system;
textWithHighlights: *Welcomes* the {{Secretary-General}}’s call for a new Bretton Woods moment to place the dramatic needs of {{developing countries}} at the centre of every decision and mechanism of the global financial system;

text: Reaffirms the need to step up coordination of macroeconomic policies among countries to avoid negative spillover effects, especially in developing countries;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the need to step up coordination of macroeconomic policies among countries to avoid negative spillover effects, especially in {{developing countries}};

text: Calls for the fulfilment of the commitment to pursue policy coherence and an enabling environment for sustainable development at all levels and by all actors and to reinvigorate the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: reinvigorate the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development
deliverables.deliverable: reinvigorate the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development

textWithHighlights: *Calls for* the fulfilment of the commitment to pursue [[policy coherence]] and an [[enabling environment]] for sustainable development at all levels and by all actors and to [[reinvigorate the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development]];
uncertainties: No explicit assignees are identified ("by all actors" is too generic). Classification of "reinvigorate the Global Partnership for Sustainable Development" as a strategy is approximate; it could also be viewed as a policy/initiative.

text: Reaffirms the recommitment to broadening and strengthening the voice and participation of developing countries, including African countries, the least developed countries, landlocked developing countries, small island developing States and middle-income countries, as well as countries and peoples under foreign occupation, in international economic decision-making, norm-setting and global economic governance, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, to deliver more equitable, effective, credible, accountable and legitimate institutions that are more responsive to the needs and concerns of developing countries;

mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity_normalized: countries and peoples under foreign occupation
mentioned_entities.mentioned_entity: countries and peoples under foreign occupation

textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the recommitment to broadening and strengthening the voice and participation of {{developing countries}}, including {{African countries}}, {{the least developed countries}}, {{landlocked developing countries}}, {{small island developing States}} and {{middle-income countries}}, as well as {{countries and peoples under foreign occupation}}, in international economic decision-making, norm-setting and global economic governance, including the {{International Monetary Fund}} and the {{World Bank}}, to deliver more equitable, effective, credible, accountable and legitimate institutions that are more responsive to the needs and concerns of {{developing countries}};

text: Also reaffirms the necessity to respect the territorial integrity, national sovereignty and political independence of States;
textWithHighlights: Also *reaffirms* the necessity to respect the territorial integrity, national sovereignty and political independence of {{States}};
uncertainties: "States" is mapped to "Member States"; if the context intended a broader set of states beyond UN Members, this mapping may be slightly imprecise.

text: Calls upon States to strengthen cooperation, including through relevant organizations of the United Nations system and other relevant regional or international forums, to combat illicit financial flows in all their forms;
textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<States>> to strengthen cooperation, including through relevant organizations of the {{United Nations system}} and other relevant regional or international forums, to combat illicit financial flows in all their forms;
uncertainties: No concrete deliverable identified; the phrase “strengthen cooperation … to combat illicit financial flows” is considered too broad. Did not mark “regional or international forums” as mentioned entities due to mismatch with the predefined entity list (organizations vs. forums).

text: Reaffirms that international trade is an engine for development and sustained economic growth, as well as the eradication of poverty in all its forms and dimensions, and also reaffirms the critical role that a universal, rules-based, open, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system can play in stimulating economic growth and development worldwide, thereby benefiting all countries at all stages of development;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* that international trade is an engine for development and sustained economic growth, as well as the eradication of poverty in all its forms and dimensions, and also *reaffirms* the critical role that a universal, rules-based, open, non-discriminatory and equitable multilateral trading system can play in stimulating economic growth and development worldwide, thereby benefiting all countries at all stages of development;

text: Expresses concern over the increasing debt vulnerabilities of developing countries, the net negative capital flows from developing countries, the fluctuation of exchange and interest rates and the tightening of global financial conditions, and in this regard stresses the need to explore the means and instruments needed to achieve debt sustainability and the measures necessary to reduce the indebtedness of developing countries;
textWithHighlights: *Expresses concern* over the increasing debt vulnerabilities of {{developing countries}}, the net negative capital flows from {{developing countries}}, the fluctuation of exchange and interest rates and the tightening of global financial conditions, and in this regard *stresses* the need to explore the means and instruments needed to achieve debt sustainability and the measures necessary to reduce the indebtedness of {{developing countries}};

text: Stresses that urgent reforms are needed in the global international financial system to address the challenges of deteriorating public finances, fiscal constraints, debt, monetary and financial stability risks and the dearth of productive and sustainable investment, and in this regard welcomes the convening, in 2025, of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, in the context of the urgent need to accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and to support reform of the international financial architecture;
textWithHighlights: *Stresses* that urgent reforms are needed in the global international financial system to address the challenges of deteriorating public finances, fiscal constraints, debt, monetary and financial stability risks and the dearth of productive and sustainable investment, and in this regard *welcomes* the convening, in 2025, of the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, in the context of the urgent need to accelerate the implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the achievement of the Sustainable Development Goals and to support reform of the international financial architecture;

text: Decides to continue to advance with urgency towards a Sustainable Development Goal stimulus through the Secretary-General’s proposal at the United Nations and in other relevant forums, and reiterates his calls for action for a new allocation of special drawing rights, which should be handled according to developing countries’ needs, taking into account that special drawing rights play an important role in enabling developing countries to invest in recovery and the Goals, on the need for an increase in concessional funding from multilateral development banks and to reform the global financial system, which must include lending criteria that go beyond gross domestic product and provide a true view of the vulnerabilities faced by developing countries;

deliverables.deliverable: new allocation of special drawing rights

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Increase in concessional funding from MDBs
Reform of the global financial system

deliverables.deliverable: lending criteria that go beyond gross domestic product

textWithHighlights: *Decides* to continue to advance with urgency towards a [[Sustainable Development Goal stimulus]] through the {{Secretary-General}}’s proposal at the {{United Nations}} and in other relevant forums, and *reiterates* his calls for action for a [[new allocation of special drawing rights]], which should be handled according to {{developing countries}}’ needs, taking into account that special drawing rights play an important role in enabling {{developing countries}} to invest in recovery and the Goals, on the need for an [[increase in concessional funding]] from {{multilateral development banks}} and to [[reform the global financial system]], which must include [[lending criteria that go beyond gross domestic product]] and provide a true view of the vulnerabilities faced by {{developing countries}};
uncertainties: Classifying “Sustainable Development Goal stimulus” as a strategy deliverable is somewhat interpretive since the text commits to advancing toward it rather than implementing it outright. The mapping of “multilateral development banks” to the broader category “international financial institutions” is also an approximation.

text: Expresses concern that the global trade financing gap has increased sharply in recent years, estimated at 2.5 trillion dollars annually, and encourages multilateral development banks and development finance institutions to scale up ongoing efforts to support trade finance and seek opportunities in digital trade finance to help to narrow the trade finance gap;

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Seek opportunities in digital trade finance
deliverables.deliverable: seek opportunities in digital trade finance

textWithHighlights: *Expresses concern* that the global trade financing gap has increased sharply in recent years, estimated at 2.5 trillion dollars annually, and *encourages* <<multilateral development banks>> and <<development finance institutions>> to scale up ongoing efforts to [[support trade finance]] and [[seek opportunities in digital trade finance]] to help to narrow the trade finance gap;
uncertainties: Classified “support trade finance” as financial_resources; alternatively could be seen as general support without a specific funding element. “Seek opportunities in digital trade finance” classified as analysis; could arguably be strategy/policy.

text: Calls upon Member States and international financial institutions to provide more liquidity and long-term finance for development, especially in all developing countries, in order to enable them to achieve sustainable development, emphasizes the need to strengthen development cooperation and to increase the volume of and access to concessional finance and grants, and calls upon developed countries that have not done so to fulfil their respective official development assistance commitments, particularly to least developed countries;
textWithHighlights: *Calls upon* <<Member States>> and <<international financial institutions>> to provide [[more liquidity]] and [[long-term finance]] for development, especially in all {{developing countries}}, in order to enable them to achieve sustainable development, *emphasizes* the need to strengthen development cooperation and to increase the volume of and access to concessional finance and grants, and *calls upon* <<developed countries>> that have not done so to fulfil their respective [[official development assistance commitments]], particularly to {{least developed countries}};

text: Reiterates the significance of addressing the constraints on technology transfer to developing countries, including the transfer of sound technology from developed countries to developing countries on favourable terms, including on concessional and preferential terms;
textWithHighlights: *Reiterates* the significance of addressing the constraints on technology transfer to {{developing countries}}, including the transfer of sound technology from {{developed countries}} to {{developing countries}} on favourable terms, including on concessional and preferential terms;

text: Reaffirms the full permanent sovereignty of every State over its natural resources and all economic activities, and calls for enhanced international cooperation to develop mineral value chains, among other natural resources, for economic diversification, value addition at source, industrialization and sustainable development;
textWithHighlights: *Reaffirms* the full permanent sovereignty of {{every State}} over its natural resources and all economic activities, and *calls for* enhanced international cooperation to develop mineral value chains, among other natural resources, for economic diversification, value addition at source, industrialization and sustainable development;
uncertainties: No explicit assignee for “calls for”; the phrase “develop mineral value chains” could be read as a deliverable but is broad/vague, so no deliverable was annotated.

text: Decides to continue considering the international economic situation and its impact on development at its eighty-first session, and in that regard requests the Secretary-General to include in his report to the General Assembly, under the item entitled “Globalization and interdependence”, an updated overview of the major international economic and policy challenges for equitable and inclusive sustained economic growth and sustainable development and of the role of the United Nations in addressing those issues, as well as possible ways and means to overcome those challenges, bearing in mind the outcomes of the major United Nations conferences and summits in the economic, social and related fields and the principles contained therein, and the 2030 Agenda, in the light of the relevant principles contained in the Declaration and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order.

deliverables.deliverable_normalized: Continue consideration of the international economic situation at the eighty-first session
Updated overview of major international economic and policy challenges and the UN role
Possible ways and means to overcome those challenges

textWithHighlights: *Decides* to [[continue considering]] the international economic situation and its impact on development at its eighty-first session, and in that regard *requests* the <<Secretary-General>> to include in his report to the {{General Assembly}}, under the item entitled “Globalization and interdependence”, an [[updated overview]] of the major international economic and policy challenges for equitable and inclusive sustained economic growth and sustainable development and of the role of the {{United Nations}} in addressing those issues, as well as [[possible ways and means]] to overcome those challenges, bearing in mind the outcomes of the major {{United Nations}} conferences and summits in the economic, social and related fields and the principles contained therein, and the 2030 Agenda, in the light of the relevant principles contained in the Declaration and the Programme of Action on the Establishment of a New International Economic Order.
uncertainties: Classifying “continue considering” as a ‘review’ (rather than a ‘meeting’) is somewhat interpretive. “Possible ways and means” is treated as ‘recommendations’ even though they are to be included within an updated overview. “United Nations” is normalized to ‘UN’ under the UN Secretariat category per the provided list.

text: 54th plenary meeting
19 December 2024
